009package imagingbook.common.geometry.ellipse.project;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
012import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.add;
013import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.multiply;
014import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.subtract;
015import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.transpose;
016import static java.lang.Math.abs;
017import static java.lang.Math.copySign;
018import static java.lang.Math.cos;
019import static java.lang.Math.sin;
020
021import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
022import imagingbook.common.geometry.ellipse.GeometricEllipse;
023
024/**
025 * <p>
026 * Abstract superclass for ellipse projectors, used to find the
027 * closest "contact" point on an ellipse for some given target point.
028 * Defines specific methods for calculating minimum distance only, 
029 * i.e., without returning the closest point itself.
030 * All calculations are performed in a "canonical" coordinate frame,
031 * with the ellipse centered at the origin and its major axis aligned
032 * to the x-axis. See Sec. 11.2.2 (Fig. 11.7) of [1] for details.
033 * </p>
034 * <p>
035 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
036 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
037 * </p>
038 * 
039 * @author WB
040 * @version 2022/11/17
041 * 
042 */
043public abstract class EllipseProjector {
044        
045        private final double[] xc;
046        private final double[][] R, Rt;                 // rotation matrix
047        
048        protected EllipseProjector(GeometricEllipse ellipse) {
049                this.xc = new double[] {ellipse.xc, ellipse.yc};
050                this.R = new double[][]
051                                {{ cos(ellipse.theta), -sin(ellipse.theta) }, 
052                                 { sin(ellipse.theta),  cos(ellipse.theta) }};
053                this.Rt = transpose(R);
054        }
055        
056        // methods to be implemented by subclasses ----------------------------
057        
058        /**
059         * Calculates the projection point in canonical coordinates.
060         * 
061         * @param u1 target point in canonical coordinates.
062         * @return the associated "contact" point on the ellipse
063         */
064        protected abstract double[] projectCanonical(double[] u1);
065        
066        // -------------------------------------------------------------------
067        
068        /**
069         * Projects the specified point onto the associated ellipse.
070         * 
071         * @param x the 2D point to be projected
072         * @return the closest point on the ellipse
073         */
074        public double[] project(double[] x) {
075                double[] u = toCanonicalFrame(x);                                       // target point in u/v coordinates
076                double[] u1 = toFirstQuadrant(u);                                       // target point in quadrant 1
077                double[] ub1 = projectCanonical(u1);                            // contact point in quadrant 1
078                double[] ub = fromFirstQuadrant(ub1, u);                        // contact point in u/v coordinates
079                return this.fromCanonicalFrame(ub);                                     // contact point in x/y coordinates
080        }
081        
082        /**
083         * Projects the specified point onto the associated ellipse.
084         * 
085         * @param pnt the 2D point to be projected
086         * @return the closest point on the ellipse
087         */
088        public Pnt2d project(Pnt2d pnt) {
089                return Pnt2d.from(project(pnt.toDoubleArray()));
090        }
091        
092        /**
093         * Calculates the distance to the closest ellipse point
094         * (but not the point itself).
095         * @param x the 2D point to be projected
096         * @return the distance to the closest ellipse point
097         */
098        public double getDistance(double[] x) {
099                return Math.sqrt(getDistanceSq(x));                     // d = ||u1 - ub1||
100        }
101        
102        public double getDistanceSq(double[] x) {
103                double[] u = toCanonicalFrame(x);                                       // target point in u/v coordinates
104                double[] u1 = toFirstQuadrant(u);                                       // target point in quadrant 1
105                double[] ub1 = projectCanonical(u1);                            // contact point in quadrant 1
106                return sqr(u1[0] - ub1[0]) + sqr(u1[1] - ub1[1]);       // = ||u1 - ub1||^2
107//              return Matrix.normL2squared(Matrix.subtract(u1, ub1));
108        }       
109
110        // internal methods projecting points to/from canonical coordinates:
111        
112        protected double[] toCanonicalFrame(double[] xy) {
113                return multiply(Rt, subtract(xy, xc)); // point in canonical coordinates
114        }
115        
116        protected double[] fromCanonicalFrame(double[] uv) {
117                return add(multiply(R, uv), xc);
118        }
119        
120        protected double[] toFirstQuadrant(double[] uv) {
121                return new double[] {abs(uv[0]), abs(uv[1])};
122        }
123        
124        protected double[] fromFirstQuadrant(double[] uv, double[] uvOrig) {
125                return new double[] {copySign(uv[0], uvOrig[0]), copySign(uv[1], uvOrig[1])};
126        }
127
128}
